subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery
with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we are going to reflect on a person who
has been very important in my life, Arthur
M. Young.
Many of you who are regular viewers of this series will know that I refer to him often
as a person who was instrumental in my development and I've called him a mentor.
With me today is Dr. Kenneth Pelletier, who actually introduced me to Arthur M. Young
back in 1972.
Dr. Pelletier is a professor of medicine at the University of California Medical Center
in San Francisco.
He is the author of many books, including
Toward a Science of Consciousness, Longevity,
and most recently, Change Your Genes, Change Your Life.
Welcome again.
Good.
Thank you.
It's good to be here.
We were reflecting earlier on what a seminal
time it was back in the 1970s when we were
graduate students at Berkeley.
As I recall, there was a group of graduate
students who met regularly to explore latest
developments related to consciousness.
You brought Arthur M. Young to that group for a series of seminars at Berkeley.
Yes.
I actually met Arthur three hours, three years earlier, around 1969.
I was at the University of Pennsylvania in this MD-PhD program.
I saw a little brochure about a man who was
coming to speak about the convergence between
science and mysticism, and I thought, fascinating,
if anyone can speak to that, I'm interested.
I went to his lecture, and honestly, I
thought everything he was saying was nonsense.
I just hated everything I was hearing, and what
I realized is that everything I was hearing
was totally different than anything I had ever been taught and trained to know.
That's why I was offended.
He and I were then going back and forth, bantering
at the end of his lecture, and he stayed behind
with some students.
I was outside the lecture hall sitting on the steps, and Arthur came back out, turned
around and came over to me and said, thank you for your questions.
They were very provocative, and I said to him, I don't know if they were provocative
or if they were just antagonistic, if I should
be proud or apologize, and he said, no, no,
I love it.
I love the interaction, and he said, and then
we started at it again, just going to it.
He said, well, listen, I've got to get home for dinner, Ruth, his wife, Ruth Young, he
would never forgive me if I got home late for dinner, he said, but I have a Saturday
morning meeting at my house in Philadelphia, and
I invite some physicists, chemists, astrologers,
doctors, you name it, I invite about seven or eight people, we have breakfast and we
have a discussion, an open-ended discussion about mysticism and science for the rest of
the morning.
Would you like to come?
I said, sure, why not?
That was the beginning of getting to know Arthur.
One of his characteristics, one that I loved
about him, and I hope I emulate myself, is
he encouraged people to challenge him, he enjoyed it when people disagreed with him.
He did, and my takeaway all these years, all
these decades later, is he probably had the
same impact on you.
He taught you how to think, how to think critically,
not to accept something because everybody else
thought that way or because it was a prevailing
scientific dogma, but how to really think
your way through what were the underlying
assumptions, is it the local version of reality
as opposed to a reality, and how to ask the really telling questions.
I mean, he was amazing at doing that.
He not only would challenge you, but he was always challenging himself, and in doing so
he gave you a roadmap.
How do you ask critical questions about your own belief systems?
What do you believe is true, and how do you find out if it is or isn't?
It's astounding.
Well, by the time I met him, when you really
were arranged to bring him to Berkeley, he
had just published his, I think it was his first book, The Reflexive Universe.
Yes.
Well, he, I left University of Pennsylvania,
went back to UC Berkeley, and this led to
the group that you're describing.
I was moving into an apartment on the north side of Berkeley, and the person moving out
was a student of Hal Puthoff, so the very
prominent, even at that time, was a very prominent
physicist at Stanford Research Institute.
And so we began talking, and he said, gee, and I told him, for some reason I told him
about Arthur.
I don't even know why.
And he said, well, this sounds like he and
Hal should meet because Al's a genius, sounds
like Arthur's a genius, and let's get them together.
So I invited Arthur out to SRI, he and Hal Puthoff met, and they were like peas in a
pod.
I mean, it was just this electricity flowing back and forth between them.
I remember Hal at one point said, well, I'm
well-versed in Scientology, I'm an OT10, which
is the operating fate and top of the Scientology
scale, and Arthur said, yes, well, yes, I
did that about 20 years ago, that kind of gruff voice, and Hal's eyes just lit up.
That was it, for Hal and Arthur.
That was the bond, I think, that made their
friendship really endure, a kind of appreciation
of their mutual training.
As I recall now, Arthur went through Dianetics even before Scientology.
Correct.
It was actually Dianetics with L. Ron Hubbard.
Yeah, and he became a Dianetic clear.
Yes, exactly.
That's exactly what he did.
So Hal was very impressed by that.
He had this study group, the one that you were just describing, largely people from
SRI and Berkeley and the San Francisco Bay Area.
So Arthur then began coming out more often and engaging with this group, and he just
got to love it.
He thought, well, this is more receptivity, more good thinking than I've had in a long
time.
So he moved out, and I believe it was probably
1970 or 71, just going back in time, where
he bought the Institute.
73, okay.
It was on Benvenu Avenue, and invited me to move in, along with my buddy Saul Paul
Serag, who's been a guest on this show as well.
These are wonderful memories.
My memory of him buying the house on Benvenu
was that he had a real estate agent taking
us around, myself and Joan Schleicher, who
still runs now the Anadose Foundation, which
was funded from Arthur's estate.
And preserves his work.
Yes, preserves his library, the original writings,
the original notebooks, his original charts,
his astrological charts, just this huge repository of information.
So we were going around looking at various houses, and we came to the Benvenu house,
and Arthur looked at it, and Ruth said, well,
we could live in the back, and the front would
make a great room for a meeting.
And so we were sitting in the front room, and the real estate agent said, well, you
know, and she started rattling off, however,
you know, you could finance the purchase of
this.
And Arthur, in his very quiet way, said, well, couldn't we just pay cash?
And literally, the real estate agent blanched white and sat down.
I don't think she'd ever heard those words
before, and just said, well, I guess we could
do that.
And Arthur said, well, fine.
Let me know how much the check is.
And that was the beginning of the purchase of
the Institute for the Study of Consciousness.
We should let our viewers know that Arthur
had, by that time, already invented the Bell
helicopter.
Correct.
In fact, that was back in the 1940s, the first commercially licensed helicopter.
Yes, it was at the time before Arthur's called
Bell Aircraft, and he went to work for Bell
Aircraft, and he had built models of the helicopter.
He has a farm, or it had about a hundred acre
farm in Downingtown, which was about 90 miles
west of Philadelphia.
And he had a barn, a beautiful barn with
downstairs and big glass doors and all of this.
And Arthur, you know, he's quite an eccentric character.
So he had models, had built up the helicopter,
and he was talking about how he'd go out in
the fields in Pennsylvania and do this vertical takeoff.
And there was this farmer watching him, being
astounded that anything could take off vertically
like that.
And Arthur asked him if he wanted a ride, would he like to take a ride?
The farmer said, yeah, sure, I'll take a ride.
So they took off and came down, and Arthur said, well, what'd you think of that?
And the farmer said, well, it's okay, but I never put my full weight down.
Arthur loved that story.
And in his barn, so that was, again, part of this.
So when I first met him in Philadelphia, then
we would go out to his mainly summer home.
And in the barn, he had the original Bell helicopter.
I mean, the first one, model 47.
And it's the one that you see now, it's the one
with the glass bubble, the traffic helicopter,
the rescue helicopters.
I believe that one of them is now in the permanent
collection of the Smithsonian Air and Space
Museum.
It's actually at the MoMA, which is even more interesting.
So Ruth was very involved in the arts, and so
the Museum of Modern Art in New York approached
Ruth and Arthur about having his original helicopter on display in the MoMA.
So now, when you walk into the MoMA in the main
atrium, if you look over your head, there's
a helicopter suspended.
That's the original Bell 47 helicopter out of Arthur's barn in Downingtown.
And he made a huge amount of money, obviously, from the helicopter.
It became Bell Helicopter, changed from Bell
Aircraft to Bell Helicopter, and Larry Bell
was, and he were good friends.
But with the initial money from that, that was probably 1948, with the original money
from that, he and Ruth took two years, they made a list of the 50 most prominent people
in the world at that time.
So they were like Wilhelm Reich, Carl Jung,
Einstein, Heisenberg, just the eminent people
of his time, and they went and visited them.
And I know he met Bertrand Russell.
Met Bertrand Russell.
So he and Ruth just did two years.
When he came back in 1952, realized that they
were all, whether they were psychics, and
he met a lot of psychics, a lot of mediums,
the Theosophical Society was alive and well,
very vibrant in London at the time.
So there was this convergence between physics
and science and metaphysics and mediumship
and all of these odd things.
When he came back, he realized they were kind
of trying to speak a similar language and
point at an underlying reality that united them all.
And that's when he founded the Institute for the Study of Consciousness in 1952.
What really impressed me about Arthur is that he
set out to develop, invent really, a helicopter,
not for the sake of the engineering or the,
yeah, that he was even interested in engineering.
It was for him to prove that he was worthy to
do philosophy, which was his real interest.
Exactly.
That is astounding that kind of on the way
to being a philosopher, he happened to invent
the helicopter.
And the specific thing he did was what was called the artificial horizon.
So one of the problems with early helicopters was instability.
The rotary blade would get out of kilter, the
helicopter would crash, and a lot of helicopter
crashes.
So what Arthur did was realize that you put a small bar, basically at a right angle to
the main blade, called the artificial horizon.
And that established literally an artificial horizon that stayed constant.
So the blade would tilt around this artificial horizon.
That's what gave the helicopter its stability.
That was the breakthrough.
So he didn't, and he had actually gone to, the
way he discovered the helicopter, or thought
of inventing it, was he went to the patent office.
Back in 1926, as I recall.
Yes.
And he wanted to find something that needed inventing.
I mean, literally.
He went in and said, so what needs inventing?
And there were things like the television,
and there were even wireless telephone things
at that time.
And he thought the helicopter was kind of fascinating.
I seem to recall he noted that there had been 200 unsuccessful patent applications.
Yes.
So basically, he thought, well, it'd be the 200, or end that losing streak.
And he stuck with it.
He spent most of, I don't know, well over a decade working on designs that just didn't
work.
Yes, correct.
I mean, he had, in this barn in Downingtown,
the lower part of the barn was the machine
shop.
So, and you've got all these wrecks in there.
Little models, big models, full scale things.
It just looked like a trash bin, but it was all the failed experiments.
And he never considered any experiment to be a failure.
It was just that that was the next step.
So it was a wrong step, let's try the next step.
This is a wrong step, that's a next.
Oh, here's a partially right step, let's take that one.
And the other thing that's kind of, you know,
is more personal reflection, is that when
he made his, the millions and millions from
the helicopter part of his tour through Europe
is he collected Rolls Royces.
So he had, in the upstairs of the barn, which is
a badminton court where he stored the original
Bell 47 was stored in that floor, he had a Rolls Royce limousine that the only other
one in the world was owned by the Shah of Iran.
So there were just two of them.
Then he had another one that was a black limousine,
and he had the audacity to cut the back of
the limousine off, and he made a pickup truck out of it.
I saw that.
Do you remember that?
I visited him there, yeah.
And he got a nasty letter from Rolls Royce saying
that he had defiled one of their automobiles
and you know, just this hell-fired brimstone about what he had done.
So when he founded the Institute for the Study
of Consciousness, he actually on the door
had inscribed in very beautiful calligraphy
a foundation for the Study of Consciousness,
because the truck was the foundation for his farm and moving all this stuff around.
So he always had this incredible sense of humor, incredible sense of humor.
And he held meetings at his home in Downingtown
for many, many, many years, and again would
have psychics come in, and physicists, and
astrologers, physicians, and he'd have these
little soirees.
There'd be about ten people that he would invite into his home.
So that was his West, East Coast version.
But he just was so enthralled by the intellectual
activity of the people like yourself and Hal
and Ed Mitchell from the Noetic Sciences that
he met on the West Coast, he decided to migrate,
to move.
So the 1970s was a very seminal period for me personally, but I think for the field of
parapsychology as well, it seemed like the whole world was going to change back then
because of the consciousness research that was being done.
The world didn't change then, but it's moving along.
And Arthur was instrumental in funding important studies back then.
He was.
One of the other people that I connected Arthur
to was to Ed Mitchell, and this was right
after his return from his flights around the moon.
And they got along famously.
They were just like, again, it was like he had Hal put off.
They were just famous friends.
And a mutual friend of theirs was Andrew Puharich,
the physician who had studied psychics and
mediums and actually had studied the Israeli
psychic Uri Geller, and had brought him over
to New York and did some work at Andrea's house in New York.
So Arthur decided he would fund bringing Uri
Geller to the Stanford Research Institute
so that scientists here could see, could they
debunk this supposed psychic who could bend
a metal at a distance and do psychic phenomena?
And so I remember in the car, it was Arthur, myself, I was driving.
So I was driving, Arthur, Andrew Puharich, and picking up Uri Geller at SFO.
I mean, that was the electricity in the car was just enough to almost levitate it.
We were all just giddy about this time.
And one of the things we did is we brought
Uri to the SRI, and they had a vacuum chamber
with I believe it was titanium suspended between two posts.
Now titanium can't bend, it can only break because of the nature of it as a substance.
So they had a titanium bar suspended between
these two posts inside an electromagnetically
shielded vacuumed container.
And there was probably 50 predominantly physicists
sitting all around it, and they basically
challenged Uri Geller to make a difference, bend this, break it, do something.
And it probably took him, I mean, he was really
concentrating in the way that when you see
him do this, you know that he's in the groove.
And all of a sudden, this piece of titanium just bent.
And it was audible.
I mean, the gasp in the room was audible.
When they examined under electron microscope
this bent piece of titanium, which should
not happen, that's a physical impossibility,
what they found is that rather than it actually
bending, it turned out the molecules, or the
electrons, I'm sorry, had migrated away from
the point of the bend into the other part of the piece of metal.
So it's like he hadn't really bent it as much
as move molecules, almost like he melted it.
And that was one of those astounding episodes.
So again, it was, you're right, this sense of
awe, that things were really going to change,
that this was going to make, and it has, it's
made a difference, I mean, many of the people
we're talking about are still around, still alive, still working, still having a great
impact.
But the sheer, let's take the renaissance,
the interaction among these people that were
really brought together by Arthur and the activity around him was astounding.
Well, it was in this timeframe that you wrote,
I think it was your first book, Mind as Healer,
Mind as Slayer?
Yes.
Yes.
I assume Arthur had some influence there.
He did, because Arthur introduced me to meditation.
So we would do these, his predominant, well,
we did it in Berkeley too, but he would have,
we'd meet on a Saturday morning, and it'd
be some subject matter that he would choose,
like biology, or chemistry, or physics, some
kind of bone-breaking subject that would,
you know, and he'd say, we're going to study this this morning.
So we'd meet in the morning, have a little
bit of, you know, coffee, and then we'd have
this lesson, the only way to describe it, of his kind of, this is what conventional
chemistry says, here's what I think is really the case.
And he was building his model, the V-shaped model of the universe, basically.
And he was thinking through parts of it, and
I got a chance to think through the parts
of it with him.
And then we would end, we would either start
the day and or end the day with a meditation.
And I didn't know what meditation was, I mean, I had no idea, and it was wonderful.
And so in the course of that, I then, at UC
Berkeley, did an undergraduate course in Tibetan
Buddhism, I'm sorry, in basically Zazen Buddhism,
and I thought, well, this is an easy course,
I'll take it for a year.
And so I did, and that got me hooked on meditation.
So part of the Buddhist philosophy is the
mind is the slayer of the real, but only the
slayer can slay the slayer.
So mind is slayer was always there, describing meditation.
And at the time, I also had been working with
Jack Schwartz, and other meditators with this
self inflicted wounds.
So I was, and I began just writing these things down, thinking about them out loud.
And suddenly one morning, I woke up and mind is healer was there.
So mind is healer, mind is slayer, was there
as a book title, and it really grew out of
the meditation practice that Arthur engendered.
Arthur paid for some of the research with Jack Schwartz and the others.
So again, he was, he was instrumental in doing that.
I think it's fair to say that the whole field
that is now known as integrative health kind
of emerged from the work you did.
Well, well, thank you.
That's kind of you.
Well, and I've certainly read other people crediting you, it's not just my opinion.
I've heard that as well.
It's almost overwhelming to think of.
I mean, I'm humbled by that, because that wasn't, you know, it wasn't my intent.
But it was, it was mind boggling, it was really quite dazzling.
This was the first time that unequivocally,
we demonstrated that your mind had regulation
over your bodily functions.
Mind-body became, became real.
And this is one of those sidebar stories, but
after I did the early demonstration project
with Jack, there was a writer from Playboy magazine, who got wind of it, I don't even
know how, they came out and did this interview.
Now I never realized how many people in
prison and the military read Playboy magazine.
I got inundated with letters, no internet at the time, letters saying, well, I can do
that, or I've done that.
So then we lined up a whole series, largely of
criminals, who had developed these extraordinary
abilities.
They have a motivation.
Well, one of them, one of them was a drug smuggler who was in prison on San Quentin.
And he said, well, I can do that, because I've been shot and stabbed.
And in order not to cry out and be discovered
and arrested, I had to control my bleeding,
I had to control my pain, I had to control
infection, because I couldn't go to a doctor.
So we brought him in and he did his demonstration.
And his particular trick was to take bicycle
spokes, sharpened bicycle spokes, put them
through the cheeks of his face, so in one side, through his mouth, and out the other.
And the photograph we ended up publishing with the study was him with his mouth open,
obviously in a trance, you can see his eyes roll back, with the bicycle spokes crossing
inside of his mouth, and he looked like a cat with six steel whiskers.
So again, it was this, it was just this time
of like a spark, like something was going
on here that we didn't understand.
And people really galvanized around that, like around Uri Geller, around Ed Mitchell,
you know, Russell Targ was Hal's kind of partner at the time, SRI was a real hotbed
of this kind of work.
And it was, and still remains, a special time.
So you know, I think by virtue of us being part of that, I think we're both fortunate.
I think kind of the universe gives you a wink
and a nod, and sometimes you just show up
at the right place.
Well, the Institute for the Study of Consciousness
was featured in a book you may know by David
Kaiser called How the Hippies Saved Physics, and
many of the people involved in that particular
movement to look at the role of what we now
call entanglement in physics and how it might
be related to consciousness, really came out
of that circle that Arthur had brought around
him.
Yes.
And I remember that Fritjof Capra had written
the Tao of Physics at about that time, and
he became part of the Institute Constellation.
Rupert Sheldrake was part of that group as well.
And again, these are people who have had this
enormous impact, and we still, to this day,
have not realized the full wisdom and insight that they've brought forward.
Wing theory and entanglement theory has grown
directly out of that hotbed of thinking in
the 70s, which really overturned Newtonian
physics and really began to realize that with
quantum physics was a whole new practical level of impact that the theories had and
the people had.
For benefit of our viewers, I might say a few things that Arthur contributed.
He had this notion that you could take an idea, like the periodic table of elements,
and apply it to everything.
Yes.
Yes, he did.
And probably his greatest contribution was what he called the grid.
It was a V-shaped arc.
And he, I think, way ahead of his time or
consistent with sages for thousands and thousands
of years, and all the great religions and
philosophies, is that consciousness was superordinate
to matter.
And the V marked the descent of consciousness
into physical matter, and then how consciousness
would turn at the base and begin to operate,
to experience, to grow in its breadth and
grow in its wisdom through stages of growth like a plant, through motion as an animal
and so on, up to the point of enlightenment and transcendence.
And it was a seven by seven matrix, and it was, in fact, fashioned after the periodic
table.
So it's a periodic table of consciousness.
And we talked in our earlier discussion about
epigenetics, how the turning point itself
is right where the DNA molecule is.
And Arthur had some significant scientific insights into the nature of DNA that really
were way ahead of his time.
Oh, far ahead of his time.
I think we haven't even really, if they get
rediscovered in the next decade, I'll be astounded.
But at the turn, he predicted that these two
qualities of the DNA, which we now know to
be accurate, and this is, we need to know in like the last six months, is when these
articles have come out.
So one is that the DNA is a superconductor at room temperature, which is unheard of.
There's no other substance, no other life
form, no other molecule in the universe that
is a superconductor at room temperature, at ambient temperature.
Superconductors do not exist.
He predicted that it did, and there is theory
now by some physicists at Princeton, which
is Arthur's alma mater, that in fact, the DNA
core is a superconductor at ambient temperature.
That's astounding.
The second is that he believed that light, the
photon, was the basic unit of communication,
of physicality, if you will.
It's not really physical, but the physicality
of the universe was manifest in light.
We know that the DNA emits light.
So if you take these two properties, a superconductor
core that emits light, those are both outside
of space, outside of time.
And Arthur basically theorized that this was de
facto evidence of the influence of consciousness.
Something that is not in the material world,
not limited by three-dimensional reality,
that it had a transcendence in space and a
transcendence in time, and it was represented
in the DNA structure at the base of this V, which then led to the evolution of life as
we know it.
So this is 50, maybe 60 years ago that he had this insight.
That's staggering.
That's absolutely astounding.
And I know Arthur was criticized by Ken Wilber,
the philosopher, for his emphasis on the photon,
as if Arthur was trying to make the photon
some sort of mechanical basis of consciousness.
That's not really where he was coming from at all.
No, not at all.
His point about the photon is that, just as
we said, which is it's outside of space, it's
outside of time, and that it has no form.
It's timeless, it's formless, it's outside
of what we know as three-dimensional reality.
So he saw it as a representation of spirit,
that the photon, if you will, is a basic unit
of analysis.
And if you think about the way that mediums
describe entities that they talk with, these
entities are often described as a point of light.
They're not described as entities as you and
I sitting here, they're described as points
of light that convey information.
So it's not far off, and again, way ahead of its time.
Arthur would never be reductionistic in terms.
The other is that the other property of the photon is you cannot locate its position in
space and time.
You can locate its position, but then the time is off.
You can locate it in time, but you couldn't,
it's the Heisenberg uncertainty principle.
And that, for Arthur, was again an indication
that there's something inherently elusive
about the physical universe, which may require
something more encompassing, more superordinate,
like consciousness, in order to complete our understanding.
And of course, we also know that from Einstein,
if you're traveling at the speed of light
along with a photon, time stops completely.
Correct.
Absolutely correct.
Absolutely correct.
To me, that's an amazing finding.
I would totally agree.
It may take me several more lifetimes just to digest the implications of it.
That's how I feel about Arthur's work, is the more I learn, the less I know, but the
more I appreciate the elegance of Arthur's thinking, the clarity of it.
He would write in these large 12 by 20 notebooks,
and I think he has hundreds of volumes of
this information.
He would just write every day.
He would be writing physics or chemistry or astrology or psychic phenomena.
He investigated psychic phenomena in a very
rigorous way and got to know some very exciting
people from the Theosophical Society, from
Joan Grant, who is the famous British medium
who wrote that whole series of books like My Life as Corolla.
Far Memory.
Far Memory.
Yes.
Far Memory actually was a real influence early on.
They're wonderful novels.
I mean, they read like novels.
According to Joan Grant, they are her past
life memories, but they're beautifully written
and very emotionally powerful.
Very powerful.
One of the things that, again, this has got to do with personal reminiscences, but one
of the things, since Arthur knew I was going
into this area of mind-body medicine, he wanted
me to basically be exposed to Joan and her husband, K, Dennis Kelsey.
Who was a psychiatrist.
Psychiatrist.
He was a member of the Royal Society and a British psychiatrist.
So I went to Arcachon.
They had a house in the west of France and went to their home and stayed with them for
a period of time to kind of learn and all these wonderful things.
And what was always mind-boggling about it was that I'd be kind of sleeping and Joan
would come in in the morning and sit down on
the side of the bed and go, now, that dream
you had last night where you're walking down
the path and you went down the right side
of the road.
Bad move.
You should have gone down the left.
Really?
Yeah.
Oh, yeah.
Oh, yeah.
It was phenomenal.
And tonight, when you repeat that dream, you
remember to turn left at the fork in the road
and you'll have a different experience.
So she was just, you know, a phenomenal, uncanny, really quite an amazing woman.
And in far memory is the book where he, Dennis,
would write as a psychiatrist looking at a
patient and the Western medical diagnostic and explanatory model.
Joan would then write a chapter about what it was for her as a medium and psychic to
see that same person.
And they went back and forth with the book.
And that was a still is a phenomenal book, which gives you a view of one reality and
the other.
But where's the overlap?
And how significant is it to have both perspectives?
So they were very influential on me and a
lot of other people, again, through Arthur's,
you know, connection.
